original_data.question:
A 9-year-old boy is brought in by his mother because of bruising on his torso and limbs. The patient’s mother denies any other symptoms and says he is otherwise healthy. Physical examination shows multiple petechiae and bruising on the torso and extremities bilaterally. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable. A complete blood count is normal. His coagulation profile reveals:
Prothrombin time (PT) 12 sec
Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) 60 sec
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

model_response:
The patient’s laboratory results show a normal platelet count, normal PT, and prolonged aPTT. This pattern of results is consistent with hemophilia A. Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder that results in a deficiency of factor VIII. The PT is normal because extrinsic coagulation, which is measured by the PT, is not affected. The aPTT is prolonged because the intrinsic coagulation pathway, which is measured by the aPTT, is affected. The platelet count is normal because platelet function is not affected.

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia can be ruled out because the patient’s complete blood count is normal. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia is associated with anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis.

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is associated with thrombocytopenia and a normal coagulation profile.

Von Willebrand disease is associated with a deficiency of von Willebrand factor, which is not represented by the coagulation tests.

Hemophilia B is similar to hemophilia A, but the deficiency is in factor IX.

Hemophilia C is similar to hemophilia A and B, but the deficiency is in factor XI.

###Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
To possess every necessary or normal part or component or step; having come or been brought to a conclusion.
The number of LEUKOCYTES and ERYTHROCYTES per unit volume in a sample of venous BLOOD. A complete blood count (CBC) also includes measurement of the HEMOGLOBIN; HEMATOCRIT; and ERYTHROCYTE INDICES.
The process of the interaction of BLOOD COAGULATION FACTORS that results in an insoluble FIBRIN clot.

Clotting time of PLASMA recalcified in the presence of excess TISSUE THROMBOPLASTIN. Factors measured are FIBRINOGEN; PROTHROMBIN; FACTOR V; FACTOR VII; and FACTOR X. It is used for monitoring anticoagulant therapy with COUMARINS.

A heavy, soft, whitish metal, resembling tin, with atomic number 78, atomic weight 195.084, symbol Pt. It is used in manufacturing equipment for laboratory and industrial use. It occurs as a black powder (platinum black) and as a spongy substance (spongy platinum) and may have been known in Pliny's time as "alutiae".

The time required for the appearance of FIBRIN strands following the mixing of PLASMA with phospholipid platelet substitute (e.g., crude cephalins, soybean phosphatides). It is a test of the intrinsic pathway (factors VIII, IX, XI, and XII) and the common pathway (fibrinogen, prothrombin, factors V and X) of BLOOD COAGULATION. It is used as a screening test and to monitor HEPARIN therapy.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
